Jon Hanna wrote:
> Jon Hanna wrote:
>> If however the way in which the GET causes changes is important (e.g. 
>> it's important that items in the sequence aren't lost) then the nature 
>> of the side-effect becomes important, and GET ceases to be appropriate.
> 
> An example of a case where GET is arguably not appropriate is "page hit 
> counters".

It's only inappropriate if you assume that these things are accurate. After
all, idempotency doesn't rule out side-effects completely, it just means
that you can't really depend on those side-effects and those side-effects
can't cause the system to behave differently.

K.
